title: TestNUC: Enhancing Test-Time Computing Approaches through Neighboring Unlabeled Data Consistency
author: Henry Peng Zou (University of Illinois Chicago), Zhengyao Gu (University of Illinois Chicago), Yue Zhou (University of Illinois Chicago), Yankai Chen (Cornell University), Weizhi Zhang (University of Illinois Chicago), Liancheng Fang (University of Illinois Chicago), Yibo Wang (University of Illinois Chicago), Yangning Li (Tsinghua University), Philip S. Yu (University of Illinois Chicago), ...
relevance_why: The approach of leveraging neighboring unlabeled data to enhance predictions could inform the development of innovative audio processing techniques, such as improving audio classifications or restorations through context-aware methods.
background: This research explores leveraging unlabeled data during inference to improve test-time predictions in natural language processing tasks.
contribution: TestNUC introduces a collaborative prediction approach integrating local consistency from neighboring unlabeled data to refine model outputs, achieving substantial performance improvements across diverse datasets.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Traditional test-time computing methods typically rely only on sampled outputs or prompt augmentations, overlooking the potential of unlabeled data.
technical_comparison.novelty: TestNUC innovatively incorporates neighboring unlabeled data predictions, which is shown to stabilize and enhance accuracy in predictions.

key_innovation: Combines predictions from similar nearby unlabeled instances during inference to enhance the robustness and accuracy of language model outputs.
real_world_impact: This method could lead to significant improvements in real-world applications of language models, particularly in scenarios with limited labeled data.
limitations: The paper mainly addresses classification tasks and does not demonstrate the approach on generative tasks.

new_terms.Test-time computing: **Test-time computing** refers to techniques that optimize model inference performance by utilizing additional computations or data during prediction rather than during training.

open_sourcing: The code is available at https://github.com/HenryPengZou/TestNUC
